definition:
Let $\pi$ be a set of prime numbers. A finite group $G$ is called
*$\pi$-separable* if there exists a composition series
$$\{1\}=G_0\lhd\cdots\lhd G_n=G$$ such that each $G_{i+1}/G_i$ is either
a or a .

A $\{p\}$-separable group, where $p$ is a prime number, is usually
called a *$p$-separable* group.

$\pi$-separability can be thought of as a generalization of solvability
for finite groups; a finite group is $\pi$-separable for all sets of
primes if and only it is solvable.
